story: FORMER Taoiseach Bertie Ahern has criticised the British and Irish Prime Ministers for failing to meet formally as required under the Good Friday Agreement.Mr Ahern, speaking on St Patrickrsquos Podcast, for the St Patrick Centre in Downpatrick, said that Micheaacutel Martin and Boris Johnson were obliged to have regular meetings of the British Irish Intergovernmental Conferenceand suggested ldquotalking to each other was not enough.He rejected their response to his previous criticism on the matter.ldquoBoth of them said they had been talking. Thatrsquos not the same as having a formal British Irish Intergovernmental Conference with officials and an agenda, he said.ldquoI have no objectionthey want to talk every day. Thatrsquos a good idea, but I think the institutions of the Good Friday Agreement should be followed and that means there should be a BIIC on a regular and frequent basis. That is what was signed.Speaking weeks after street violence by loyalist protesters erupted in Belfast over issues related to Brexit and the NI Protocol, Mr Ahern said BIIC meetings were very important.ldquoIt does concern me that we havenrsquot had a British Irish Intergovernmental Conference for a long, long time, maybe a few years.Mr Ahern was interviewed by former BBC political correspondent Martina Purdy and former barrister Elaine Kelly, who spoke to the former Taoiseach about peace-building, faith and St Patrick.ldquoThe two governments, the British and Irish governments are the custodians of the Agreement. They are not meeting to discuss these issues. That clearly is not in line with the agreement.ldquoI am not using any other words than what the Agreement usedhellip The agreement says that there must be frequent meetings and you know that should be happening.ldquoThey donrsquot have to be for long. They can be on zoom, Microsoft teams anything you like. They should be having these meetings and where there are dficulties they should be dealing with at those meetings.ldquoIn the absence of those meetings, things can drt. Quite frankly I donrsquot understand why those meetings canrsquot take place.ldquoI donrsquot expect the British Prime Minister and the Taoiseach to have a meeting all day ndash they donrsquot have to do that. They could have a meeting for an hour and half. Thatrsquos not going to kill anybody.He said other officials or ministers or institutions within departmental structures could then follow through with the issues.Mr Ahern also spoke about the future of the Catholic Church in Ireland, where he said there must be more involvement of the laity.He said his faith was important to him. ldquoYou donrsquot want to overplay it because you are attacked nowyou do that.ldquoReligion is important to me. I am a believer and I understand it and I read about it and I think itrsquos part of my le and I often think that a lot of people, who have a lot of problems and dficulties - it is because they donrsquot have it. All I can do is pray for them.During lockdown Mr Ahern shared how he went to mass regularly from his kitchen in Drumcondra, sharing masses online from Clonard monastery in Belfast, as well as Derry, Cork and Dublin.He said lockdown had given people time to reflect and enjoy walking, something he really enjoys.He told the podcasters mdash former Sisters of Adoration who are now pilgrim guides on Saint Patrickrsquos Way Downpatrick mdash that ldquohe would love to come and walk the Irish Camino with them.He revealed he had spent nine months of the lockdown reading The Annals of the Four Masters, chronicles of medieval Irish history.Mr Ahern described it as a ldquotough read, admitting he could only manage  pages a day.Asked what he would like to banish from Ireland, in the Spirit of St Patrick, he said ldquoinjustice and violence..prettyPhoto

title: Breastfeeding is the most beautiful thing
story: WHEN Joanne Masseyrsquos second child, Edward, was born six months ago, she knew she wanted to breastfeed him, but also,possible, donate to the milk bank.Weighing in at just over lbs, Edward fed for  minutes soon after he was born and it seemed like establishing feeding would be no problem.However, a few months before Edward was born, Joannersquos family found out her father, Jim Watson, had cancer.She explained: ldquoEventually we would learn it was terminal. So my stress levels were abnormally high.ldquoI soon felt like I couldnrsquot feed Edward enough, stress got the better of me at times and my brilliant health visitor Maura pointed me to a local breastfeeding group and also another brilliant lady, my breastfeeding peer support worker Aine Jordan-Doxey, who just completely gave me the confidence and support to keep going.ldquoThe peer breastfeeding group is hosted by a midwe health visitor and contains a beautul bunch of souls who are just there for each other. Wersquore all in the same boat and through this group I have received many tips, tricks and even friends.Despite Joannersquos determination to breastfeed Edward, it wasnrsquot all plain sailing.ldquoBreastfeeding is just the most beautul thing.Yes it can be dficult and absolutely frustrating at times but the benefits far outweigh those short blips, she said.ldquoThe best advice Irsquove ever heard mdash lsquodonrsquot give up on a bad dayrsquo.On a rough day, breastfeeding Edward gave me comfort, knowing I was the reason he is full and happy made me feel so good.ldquoAine gave me so much advice, including certain foods to eat to boost milk supply. Oats, theyrsquore your best friend! And you cannot drink enough water.Soon Joanne had more milk that Edward could take so she began collecting extra milk for the milk bank.She said: ldquoThe bottles arrived and I filled the first ml on December  last year. The donation was nearly full in a month but sadly my dad passed away on January  at the age of . There was a few weeks with no donations as my milk supply ped to an all-time low. Itrsquos just incredible what stress can do to your body.ldquoWell, Aine was there again, checking in, keeping me in chat, and keeping me motivated to keep breastfeeding. I am very lucky to have a wonderful, supportive husband, a close knit family and a close circle of best friends who have been tremendous during this very dficult time.Joanne went on to complete her donation of four litres of milk she calls ldquoliquid gold on Motherrsquos Day and wants to thank Aine for all her help and support.She said: ldquoI fully support every motherrsquos choice to either breastfeed or bottle-feed butanyone was struggling to breastfeed I would strongly recommend taking the support thatrsquos available.ldquoPersonally I am continuing to breastfeed because it gives me a little comfort in this time of grief, itrsquos a moment where I just look into his eyes and feel so needed and loved. So not only for the instantly available nutrition and comfort to my son but for those moments of joy I get from it too.Aine says she is so proud of Joanne mdash not only for continuing to breastfeed during the emotional time of her fatherrsquos illness and death but also for contributing four litres of milk to the Trustrsquos milk bank.The mother-of-threersquos own experience of breastfeeding had been rewarding but also not without its challenges.While she was living in England at the time, she recalled a time when one of her children was not thriving while she was feeding them.ldquoMy doctor and my health visitor both told me to stop breastfeeding my son and it was so frustrating as I knew that was not the problem so I continued on and it turned out that there was something  wrong.She began supporting Joanne in November last year when Edward was five weeks old.ldquoJoanne was exhausted and had been through some dficult nights where Edward wasnrsquot sleeping and was screaming through the night.I remember speaking with her about developmental leaps and what to expect at this stage and the normal infant sleep patterns, said Aine.ldquoFrom the beginning I could tell Joanne had so much passion for breastfeeding and wanted to succeed in every way. Joanne began expressing enough to give Edward a bottle and soon after he started sleeping better, just in time for her toddler to stop sleeping through. Joanne never let this stop her and carried on with minimal sleep.Aine said that when Joanne first mentioned to her about the possibility of donating milk, there were only  donors on the Northern Ireland milk bank.She said ldquoI was so proud as Joanne was the first of my mums to donate and it honestly made me smile at the thought. As usual Joanne just laughed and said it was no big deal as she enjoyed it. It was the first time I disagreed with her as I thought she was doing an extraordinary thing.ldquoWhen I opened her message and saw Edward surrounded by four litres of expressed milk for the milk bank, I was blown away again. What an incredible gt for the sick babies in theneonatal units.ldquoNot only was Joanne potty training a toddler and breastfeeding on demand, but she was expressing for the milk bank. I am so thankful to have been a part of her journey. So often there isnrsquot enough support available for mums especially with breastfeeding, and Covid made it more dficult as the usual support groups had all closed. Thatrsquos why peer support is so valuable as it provides one to one support for mums at the most important time.Aine highlighted the need for support for breastfeeding mums. ldquoWe need to be offering all mums support from the very first chance which is the case for a lot, but sometimes mums donrsquot know about us until itrsquos too late. ldquoI am thankful to Joanne for sharing this experience with me and I know we will still be in touch for a long time.ldquoAnd even though Irsquom sure she will downplay what she has achieved, I can honestly say I am so proud of her and all her hard work.Mothers can be referred to the Trustrsquos breastfeeding support worker through midwery and health visiting services..prettyPhoto

title: Carlisle’s staff in charity hike in memory of much loved Pat
story: ONE hundred staff and friends at Carlislersquos in Ballynahinch are each walking five miles this week on a sponsored walk in honour of a much-loved colleague who died last month.Pat Greene, who was from Saintfield, died on April , much to the shock and sorrow of everyone at the business.The  year-old had worked for Carlislersquos for  years, starting off as a coal boy, going on to work in all areas of the business and finishing as a work supervisor.Donna Carlisle explained that Pat loved The Proclaimers song Irsquom Gonna Beand it inspired the charity effort from staff members, past and present, and their partners.ldquoIt was Patrsquos favourite song and it had to be on the playlist at all our party nights when we raised money for ious cancer charities. Raising money for these charities was always important to Patrick as his mother sadly passed away from the disease when he was young, she said.ldquoHe never missed any of the parties and when The Proclaimers came on I always remember Pat taking centre stage and all of us had to follow him and his actions and it was always very important we did it right.ldquoThis is one memory of Pat we will never forget. We think it is very fitting that between us all we will walk those  miles for our friend and colleague whilst raising much needed funds for Cancer Focus NI in his name.The walkers aim to complete the  miles by Sunday, having started last Sunday.Mrs Carlisle praised her late colleague as a person who was ldquouniversally liked.ldquoI honestly never heard one bad word said about Pat. He was just one of those members of staff you just loved to have around you, she said. ldquoHe was brilliant, did anything and always tried to keep everyone right. He was always there and became part of the furniture, as they say.ldquoHe really became a friend over the years and he will be sorely missed by us all.Money will be raised through staff sponsorship and JustGiving donation on Carlislersquos Facebook page. Contributions can also be left into the Belfast Road shop in Ballynahinch.Carlislersquos Fuels have donated  litres of oil while Carlislersquos Food SuperValu is donating pound worth shopping vouchers for a prize draw for everyone who donates.The draw will take place on Monday, May , and winners will be contacted by Facebook page or telephone. To donate visit www.justgiving fundraising paddyswalkmiles.prettyPhoto

title: Cheers – pubs reopen
story: LOCAL beer gardens and restaurants welcomed ato business as Covid restrictions were eased last Friday.Downpatrick-based Murphyrsquos Bar and Restaurant, Denvirrsquos Coaching Inn, Turleyrsquos Bar and the Mirabelle Bar and Killough based Anchor Bar were among the public houses that reopened their doors to eager members of the public.Despite some guidelines still being in place such as track and trace and limiting the amount of households at one table together, that didnrsquot dampen the spirits of the members of the public who made full use of their favourite locals serving again.Mark Murphy, co-owner of Murphyrsquos, said he was delighted at being able to welcome back familiar faces to his premises whilst sharing a laugh or two with them throughout the day.ldquoItrsquos great. Finally after a long layoff we can resume a bit of normality in our outdoor beer garden, Mr Murphy said. ldquoWe have installed a new bar outside to coincide with the rules that are still in place and we have enjoyed creating a new look premises for the locals to enjoy, he continued.ldquoWe have missed many things but none more so than our loyal customers.Whilst soaking in the busy atmosphere, customer Sarah Taggart said: ldquoItrsquos been a long five months, I have missed the craic and seeing the dferent people around the bar. It is great to be back.Denvirrsquos also enjoyed greeting their customers, who enjoyed a meal and drinks in the beer garden.Co-owner Chris Dagens said: ldquoAfter a long time away, we can finally see our customers again. Itrsquos fantastic to see so many familiar people who we have greatly missed and long may it continue.The establishment has also been using the lsquoB expressrsquo mobile app in the beer garden so customers can order from their table and reduce further contact.ldquoThe app is great, itrsquos convenient for customers and makes it so much easier to get their orders to their tables at the fastest time. We have had great feedback on it so far and we will continue to use it, he added.Turleyrsquos have recently installed an outdoor beer garden right on time for reopening. Using the duration away from regular opening hours to his advantage, owner Kieran Turley has expanded his premises.ldquoTo reopen the doors again has been a relief. We started to expand when things were going downhill for the hospitality business and have really made use of the layoff, he said.ldquoI love seeing customers back at the bar, evenit is outdoors. The main thing is that my customers will be able to safely enjoy ato the bar, he added.Customer Siobhan Botsford said: ldquoKieran is a great host. He has taken care of us all throughout lockdown and really cares for his customers. My friends and I are regulars here because of how he treats us all.At the Mirabelle Bar in Market Street, owner Ann Blackwood was optimistic as she expressed her happiness at being allowed to invite members of the public back to their local.ldquoItrsquos so good to be back, we havenrsquot opened since October, she said.ldquoItrsquos great to see the town busy again, the shops are back open but most importantly so are the bars and hairdressers.Customer Roberta Marie McCoubrey said: ldquoIrsquom glad to be back at the bar with all my friends. Itrsquos great seeing everyone out enjoying themselves, we all deserve it.Meanwhile in Killough, the Anchor Bar have began serving the locals their favourite selection of beers, all whilst supplying sports entertainment on their outdoor television.Owner John Fitzsimmons said: ldquoIt feels absolutely brilliant to be back in action. I have missed all of the regulars so much throughout lockdown. Thankfully, it looks as though therersquos light at the end of the tunnel and we are doing everything we can to ensure a safeto all the customers.Among those enjoying the reopening was Cora Kelly, who said: ldquoItrsquos great to finally get back to a sense of normality. John has been so great throughout lockdown supplying an off-sales for the village and he always make an effort to make everyone feel as comfortable as he can when we are all here..prettyPhoto

title: Chefs cook up a treat on Great British Menu
story: TWO local chefs flew the flag with top class cuisine in last weekrsquos Northern Ireland regional heat of Great British Menu.Carryduff chef Gemma Austin mdash who is a former student of Assumption Grammar School in Ballynahinch mdash was beaten in Fridayrsquos nightrsquos decider of the BBC Two show by Londonderry chef Phelim OrsquoHagan, who will go on to represent Northern Ireland in the grand final.It was the first entry for the  year-old who is chef and co-owner of Alexanders in Holywood.Paul Cunningham, chef owner of Brunels in Newcastle, was invited back to compete in this yearrsquos competition after impressing judges last year. However, he did not make it through to show his impressive main course and dessert to the judges.Both chefs threw their all into devising four courses, including an appetiser and pre-dessert mdash based on the theme celebrating British innovation.Hopes were high for East Down given that Dundrum chef Alex Browne Greene, from EIPIC restaurant in Belfast, got two dishes to the national final last year and narrowly missed out on being crowned champion of champions at the banquet.Gemmarsquos starter was a twist on gammon, egg and chips, inspired by Kegomatic from Queenrsquos University students and for her fish course, the innovation shown in the building of the Titanic inspired her sea bass fish dish.She used William Clannyrsquos invention of the safety lamp for miners for her main course of lamb and the influence of astronomer Alice Everett as the first woman to work for the Royal Observatory to inspire her dessert, Out of this World.The dessert was her favourite course and she was delighted to have been scored a ten by chef Daniel Clford.ldquoIrsquom known for my desserts so I was really delighted to have got that score from Daniel, said Gemma.ldquoI also took his advice on my main course as therersquos no better person to take advice from and generally scaled back my dishes and made them more refined as the comments back were that there was too much on the plate.While Gemma was proud to have made it through to the regional final, she said she was not disappointed at not going through to the national judging.ldquoTo be honest, it was a bit of a relief as I did not know how I was going to go up against all the other chefs in the national final as I have only been cheffing for seven years and am mostly self-taught, she revealed.Gemma went into the competition, which was filmed last November, full of confidence and determined to do her best.ldquoI think I just went into a zone and concentrated on my own dishes and not to get too caught up in what the other chefs were doing, she said.ldquoPhelim was brilliant on the day and deserved to win and I remember saying on the programme that the better chef won. I hope that he goes on to get a dish to the banquet.While she has been receiving fantastic customer feedback from her popup, A Peculiar Tea, which she has been operating during the lockdowns, Gemma admitted that cooking was not her first career choice.ldquoWhen I left school I actually went to Queenrsquos University to do a nursing degree but a medical issue I experienced meant that I couldnrsquot complete it, she said.She then studied Bio Medical Sciences for a while before going to Ulster University to complete a software engineering degree.Her love of food and cooking mdash inspired by her chef mother mdash was strictly a hobby until the age of  when she took her first job at Slims Kitchen on the Lisburn Road in Belfast where she cut her teeth for a year while doing a Culinary Masters course.For four years Gemma continued studying and working full-time at a iety of great establishments, such as the Fitzwilliam Hotel in Belfast where she rose to head pastry chef, before moving The Old Inn, Crawfordsburn, where she worked all the sections and eventually became sous chef.She has been in Alexanders for the last two years and got the opportunity to become an owner last year.ldquoIt may have taken my several attempts before I found the right career but I was determined not to do any job that I did not absolutely love and was passionate about.Like Gemma, Brunels chef Paul Cunningham hopes to be invited back next year after his disappointing showing this year.The  year-old had hoped to get to the regional judging to please his six-year-old daughter, Farrah.ldquoFarrah and I are massive fans of the show, we watch every year and of course, I wanted to further than I did but Irsquove got over the disappointment now and concentrating on getting the restaurant ready for re-opening, Paul told the Recorder.Paul is known for only using local produce from within a -mile radius of Newcastle and foraging for herbs and plants.His menu reflected his locality and passion for pioneers including Belfast-born Dame Jocelyn Bell Burnell and Isambard Kingdom Brunelrsquos refloating of the SS Great Britain in Dundrum Bay mdash an incident which led him to name his restaurant by the great engineer.Paul only got to cook his starter and main course on the show but said his main course and dessert were showstoppers, with the main course of lamb called Healthy Heart made without using any salt or butter, inspired by Frank Pantridge who invited the portable defibrillator.He also collaborated with Doran Precision Engineering to create a model of the Titanic for one of his dishes and a special dish to show off his dessert, the Atom Smasher, inspired by Dame Jocelyn Bell Burnell..prettyPhoto

title: Condemnation over Murlough vandalism
story: LOCAL politicians have criticised vandals responsible for setting fire to a gate at the Murlough Nature Reserve two weekends ago as  firefighters were battling a huge blaze in the nearby Mournes.The vandals also left behind a trail of rubbish at the internationally acclaimed area with their actions condemned by South Down MLA Colin McGrath and Mournes councillor Laura Devlin.They say it ldquobeggars belief that while the raging wildfire destroyed  acres of rich habitat across the Mournes, there were people who thought that it was appropriate to start a fire at the Nature Reserve.The politicians also revealed that National Trust staff had to remove  bags of rubbish from the Reserve location on the Sunday the fire in the Mournes was eventually extinguished.Cllr Devlin said as young people drank alcohol and watched the blaze raging across the mountains, they set fire to a pedestrian gate which is also used to prevent Exmore ponies at the Reserve from escaping.ldquoI am really shocked at this behaviour, she said. ldquoBy the Saturday evening, everyone in the locality had an idea of the widespread damage in the Mournes but these iniduals thought it appropriate to cause more damage and potentially risk another blaze.ldquoI have no idea who these iniduals were and how old they are so I am appealing to people young and old. This is our area and it is being destroyed.Cllr Devlin said that given the ldquoawful scenes witnessed in the Mournes two weekends ago and the huge pressure on the Fire and Rescue Service, she appealed to people to be ldquorespectful and sensible.Cllr Devlin said the ecosystem at the nature reserve was ldquoincredibly delicate and that even the grazing ponies played a pivotal role in what was a very sensitive environment.She also appealed to parents to know where their children are at all times, suggesting they have conversations around the dinner table about the environment and how fortunate they are to live somewhere so beautul and the crucial role everyone has to play in it.Cllr Devlin confirmed that she has been in contact with the National Trust and is concerned that a result of the behaviour of some iniduals, the conservation charity is wasting valuable resources tidying, cleaning and repairing damage.She added: ldquoThis makes no sense and is also very unfair on National Trust rangers whose job it is to conserve and protect our surroundings..prettyPhoto

title: Danny’s delight at lifting top title
story: BALLYNOE native Danny McMenamin capped off a defining season in his young career when he was recently presented with the Conditional Champion Jockey award at Sandown Park racecourse.The up-and-coming jump jockey wrote his name into the history books alongside fellow countrymen Sir AP McCoy and Brian Hughes as a winner of the illustrious prize.Dannyreflected on his crowning moment after he produced an extremely impressive  wins from  rides to finish in first place,  wins ahead of his nearest competition.ldquoItrsquos fantastic, it really is hard to explain just how happy I am that I earned this award, he said.ldquoEvery young lad setting up wants to be the Champion Conditional Jockey, itrsquos every young mans dream. It didnrsquot sink in until I was driving away from the ceremony and it was a great feeling.The jump jockey star first began his interest in horses after watching the races at Downpatrick Racecourse with his family when he was just eight years old. Since then, he carried on visiting the local racetrack with friends and soon caught the racing bug.ldquoI went to a few point-to-pointers with the McCartan family who we know well. It wasnrsquot long after that I got on the saddle for the first time and I got going from there, said Danny.The golden boy started off with Downpatrick trainer Brian Hamilton before working with group one winning flat trainer Ger Lyons in Kildare.On the advice of former Grand National winner Tony Dobbin, Danny then made his big move across the water to Penrith in Cumbria to work under the highly respected trainer Nicky Richards at his famous Greystoke stables.ldquoI was only  when I turned professional and made the move to England. I was very nervous, but Nicky made me feel really welcomed and I settled in quickly, he recalled.ldquoIt was tough at the beginning to be fair but Nicky is very easy to get on with and he knew it was going to be dficult for me. He made things very straight forward and it didnrsquot take long for me to get the hang of things.The rider credits the first big moment of his blossoming career to when he rode the   shot Nietzsche, trained by Brian Ellison, to first place in the grade three Greatwood Handicap Hurdle at Cheltenham when he was just  in November .ldquoIt was something that was unexpected and maybe came a bit out of the blue. It really helped my career and put me on the radar to a lot of people.Danny has ridden a number of horses on his path to success but does share a special bond with one in particular.ldquoNuts Well is my favourite horse. We have competed a lot together and Irsquove developed my skills with him a lot, we have picked up six or seven wins this season together he said.ldquoThat horse has helped me get to the grade one stage of racing, especially after our massive grade two win.That grade two success was when Danny and Nuts Well secured first place in the valuable Old Roan at Aintree. Nuts Well was picked for an outsider in the race at  , but the talented rider once again showed he was worth his salt as he galloped to glory.This gave Northumberland trainer Ann Hamilton her biggest success to date as they claimed the pound, prize pot.Despite his interest and success in racing, Danny was the first in his family to become heavily involved in the sport.ldquoI come from a sporting background in my family, my two brothers played Gaelic football and soccer growingup, but I was the one who took it upon myself to get into the horses, he said.ldquoOf course my family supported me and helped me achieve were I am today, but I do not come from a racing background.Dannyrsquos parents, Brenda and Denis, were delighted as their son received recognition for an outstanding season and hope that this is just the beginning for the promising young talent.ldquoWe are so proud of him, he has done all of this off his own back, said Brenda.ldquoHe has worked extremely hard to get to this point and I am so glad he is living his dream.ldquoEven though I canrsquot watch his big hurdle races until the final straight as I always have a motherrsquos worry, she added.Danny spent a brief time back with family in Downpatrick but is getting back to business as usual in England.ldquoI just plan on keeping my head down and hope to bring the momentum from this season into the next one, he said.ldquoEverything wouldnrsquot be possible without the help from all of the team at the stables and my familyrsquos support. I want to kick on now and be the best I can be..prettyPhoto

title: Dundrum get one over on local rivals Saintfield
story: DUNDRUMrsquoS pre-season preparations continued with a victory over Saintfield on Saturday.Both teams were looking for strong performances before the season gets underway this weekend and while Saintfield were understrength, Dundrum will be pleased to have beaten a team placed a league above them.Dundrum bowled first, opening with Davy Glover and Daniel Kearsley against Saintfield batsmen Matthew Hamill and Ross Murray.Dundrum got off to a good start, building early pressure on the Saintfield batsmen and making scoring very dficult. Kearsley picked up a wicket in his first over, bowling Hamillwith a brilliant yorker.Kearsly was bowling with great pace, while Glover bowled steady line andas the two bowlers restricted Saintfield to  for one from the first five overs.Dundrum skipper James Martin came into the attack picking up a wicket in his second over to dismiss Andy McCavery .The Dundrum bowlers continued to build pressure which caused Murrayto play an aggressive shot and was bowled by Martin.In the first ten overs the home side managed to restrict Saintfield to  for three. Roy McCavery and Johnny Viner tried to counter attack for Saintfield and managed to add  runs for the next wicket in quick time. However, veteran Gavin McNerlin bowled McCavery for  in the th over.Jack Telford joined Viner and the two away team batsmen added another  runs for the next wicket. Dundrum continued to build pressure and in the th over Saintfield were only on  for four. Tom Crudgington then bowled Viner for , the top score of the day.The lower order attempted to accelerate the score, but good Dundrum bowling and fielding made it dficult for the batsmen. Saintfield eventually finished on  for seven from their  overs.The pick of the Dundrum bowlers was Martin, who finished with three for  from his four overs.Dundrum opened the batting with Greg Hutley and Stuart Campbell hoping to get off to agood start. Saintfield opened the bowling with Mark Yeates and TJ Macavery.Dundrum added  for the first wicket in five overs before Hutleywas caught off the bowling of Yeates. Yeates struck the very next ball when he bowled Campbell for .Terry Hutley was joined by McNerlin and hoping to steady the innings for Dundrum. However, McNerlin was dismissed for  when he was caught off the bowling of Ethan Hanna. Hutleywas dismissed in the next over off the bowling of Yeates.This left Dundrum  for four from nine overs. Captain Martin attempted to counter attack but was dismissed for eight off the bowling of Ross Murray.Kearsley and Andrew Foster added  for the next wicket to take the score to  for five from  overs. Hanna then bowled Fosterand Kearsleyin the same over to swing the game back to Saintfield.Gloverand Rhodri Phillips combined well in the closing overs to sneak Dundrum over the line with one over remaning to complete a three wicket win for Dundrum.The pick of the Saintfield bowlers was Ethan Hanna who finished with four for  from his four overs.Dundrum start their season this Saturday when they travel to Laurelvale in the T Shield. Saintfield also begin their season on Saturday when they host Cltonville Academy in Section ..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C May 9%2C 2001
story: SEAFORDE ndash Angry Seaforde residents, opposed to plans to site a telecommunications mast close to their homes, have called for work on the structure to be halted.They are outraged local planning chiefs failed to inform them the -metre high mast was going to be erected at the Tannaghmore Road in the village.A large number of residents have this week signed a petition objecting to the mast which is being erected by BT Cellnet and have called on local politicians Patsy Toman, Anne McAleenan and Francis Casement to help them.Mr Richard OrsquoPrey, who handed over the petition on Monday night, said none of the residents who live at the Tannaghmore Road knew anything about the mast until work to erect it began last week.He said everyone is concerned about the impact the mast could have on peoplersquos health and are annoyed they did not receive any warning from the planners that the mast was to go up.ldquoWe do not want this mast on our back doors and want people to help us fight this issue. That is why we have enlisted the help of the local councillors, he explained.CASTLEWELLAN ndash A Castlewellan bank has been targeted by armed robbers for the second time in less than two years.Thieves struck at the townrsquos First Trust Bank shortly after .pm on Wednesday afternoon and made off with an undisclosed sum of money. It is understood that no members of the public were in the premises at the time.One man, who was described as being rsquo or rsquo, dressed in a cream and beige sweatshirt, light blue jeans and dark trainers entered the Main Street building wearing what police have described as a ldquomakesht mask.After threatening a member of staff with a claw hammer, cash was handed over before the man sped off in a black Vauxhall Nova car, registration number EBZ , which had been waiting outside.The vehicle was later recovered by police at the Ballydrumman Road near Ballyward.Local police have appealed for anyone who can help with with their enquiries to contact them as soon as possible.NEWCASTLE ndash The controversial merger of two Newcastle primary schools is likely to go ahead in September on two separate sites.As the autumn deadline for the rationalisation of St Maryrsquos Girlsrsquo and Boysrsquo primary schools approaches, sources close to the Department of Education have indicated the merged school may operate on split sites for the first academic year.The growing likelihood that the new primary will operate on a split campus is expected to top the agenda of a meeting of the Board of Governors elected to oversee the management of the new school, tomorrow evening.Although no decisions have yet been taken, mixed classes are likely to be formed at Beechfield Park and Shanslieve Drive, with only primary six classes remaining unaffected by the merger to minimise disruption in their eleven plus year.The schools have been at the centre of fierce debate since their boards of governors unveiled the amalgamation proposal in .BALLYNAHINCH ndash Regeneration officials in Ballynahinch will tomorrow officially launch their ambitious scheme to redevelop the historic market house in the town square.Details of the pound, scheme will be mapped out during a special launch at the Millbrook Lodge Hotel attended by representatives from a range of funders.Local planners are expected to confirm shortly they are fully behind the plan to convert the current Market House into a new civic building, complete with office space, youth facilities and a tourist information point.The South Eastern Education and Library Board and the Youth for Christ organisation have agreed to rent part of the building, a move regeneration officials say is vital to provide them with rent to maintain the building in the future.Regeneration group chairman, Mr Vincent Fullam, says next weekrsquos launch marks the end of a long crusade to provide the people of Ballynahinch with a civic building and, at the same time, cement the historical importance of the town square for future generations.KILLYLEAGH ndash Killyleagh is to get a new war memorial. Work on the new cenotaph at the top of High Street is expected to start later this year and could be completed before the annual Remembrance Day parade in the town in November.News that money to finance the eagerly-awaited scheme has been secured has been confirmed by the DUP candidate in the forthcoming local government elections, Mr Billy Walker.For the past number of months he has been working with Strangford Assembly member Jim Shannon to raise money an has this week revealed they have secured pound, from two sources.However, the identities of the backers are being kept secret until the new scheme is formally launched within the next few weeks.Meanwhile, Mr Walker said he is delighted the provision of a new memorial is now a reality. He said it will be a fitting tribute to the men and women from the Killyleagh area who made the supreme sacrice during two world wars and other conflicts.DOWNPATRICK ndash Health officials have this week confirmed they have secured additional anaesthetic cover to ensure services continue to be provided at Downpatrickrsquos maternity unit.The move forms part of a rolling rescue plan the Down Lisburn Trust has had to put in place after the future of the unit was put at risk.Local anaesthetists threatened to withdraw out-of-hours cover at the end of January and the Trust was forced to arrange additional cover provided by Belfast-based anaesthetists. Since them, it has been reviewing the situation on a monthly basis and confirmed this week that cover remains in place for this month.The news has been welcomed by South Down MP Eddie McGrady, who said the Trust has also confirmed that it has been in contact with Belfast-based anaesthetists to ascertain their long-term commitment to the provision of services at the Downe Hospital and maternity unit.ARDGLASS ndash The crisis facing the fishing industry is to top the agenda at a special meeting hosted by the Provincersquos Agriculture Minister.The talks with Brid Rodgers are expected to take place at her Dundonald Houses headquarters within the next few weeks and involve politicians from Down, Ards and Newry and Mourne councils.Representatives for each of the three areas have already joined forces to draw up a plan to help beleaguered fishermen based in Ardglass, Portavogie and Kilkkeel and have been seeking a meeting with the Minister for some time to discuss the detail of a new strategy they have put together.Miss Rodgers was unable to make space in her diary because of her heavy involvement with the foot and mouth crisis, but she has now confirmed the talks with the local politicians will take place shortly.ANNACLOY ndash A local councillor has welcomed progress on the improvement scheme for the Annacloy Road, outside Downpatrick, and has called on the Roads Service to carry out the work ldquoas a matter of urgency.Cllr Margaret Ritchie said she has for some time been campaigning to have the section of the Annacloy Road from the Kingrsquos Bridge to the Belfast Road ldquosubstantially improved.Describing the road as ldquovery narrow and undulating, Miss Ritchie said that after discussions with Roads Service officials, she was pleased when they informed her last November that the road had been placed on an improvement programme..prettyPhoto

title: Hopes Dunleath Park can be hub for cyclists
story: DOWNPATRICK councillor Gareth Sharvin has welcomed plans to establish a cycle hub at Down Leisure Centre and Dunleath Park in partnership with Cycling Ireland.Two -foot containers will be used ndash one for hosting courses and tutoring, and the other to be used for bike storage, maintenance and a workshop facility.Last weekrsquos meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Active and Healthy Communities Committee approved the scheme, which Cllr Sharvin described as a welcome addition for Dunleath Park and Downpatrick.ldquoThis is the second project item to be planned for Dunleath Park following the SDLPrsquos motion to council calling for the development of sporting and recreational activities at the site, he said.The new cycling hub will compliment and utilise the planned build of a recreational path around the perimeter of Dunleath Park.The cycle hub is part of a new initiative by Cycling Ireland who are working in partnership with local authorities to establish similar facilities across Northern Ireland.Councillor Sharvin added: ldquoThis will be a great addition to the area of Downpatrick and the district. The cycle hub will see the establishment of an innovative and unique cycling development training project based out of Dunleath and Down Leisure Centre.ldquoThe hub will deliver courses, tutoring and programmes to the public. This is a great opportunity for Downpatrick to become a real destination for cycling..prettyPhoto

title: Hopes for Knockevin build
story: HOPES have been raised for a new build project at Knockevin Special School in Downpatrick.A Department of Education confirmed this weekthat the school will now be eligible to apply for a new build project.The news follows parents learning last week that an expected extension to replace mobile classrooms was not going ahead.A Department of Education spokesperson said: ldquoThe Education Authoritymade the dficult decision to withdraw Knockevin School from the School Enhancement Programmebased on the evidence provided by a feasibility study, which identied that theneeds of the school could not be met by the SEP project on the schoolrsquos existing constrained sites.ldquoUnder the SEP protocol, Knockevin School would not have been eligible for a new build project for seven years, had it progressed as a SEP.ldquoIn the interim, the EA has advised the Department that they intend to take forward a programme of maintenance and minor works projects at the school to address the immediate accommodation pressures and the most urgent health and safety issues..prettyPhoto

title: Jim was some player
story: THE passing of Jim Connolly is a watershed for a great many people in the County Down area.Here was a sportsman of immense standing, one of a rare breed who gave joy through his many exploits yet remained humbly rooted to an area which embraced him with the warmth afforded to a favourite son.Always approachable and amenable, Jim was never happier than being in company and sharing in the stories and experiences of those around him. He had a rare gt for making everyone feel better about themselves and for knowing they always had a friend in him. Facebook notices of his death drew an unprecedented outpouring of tributes and comments from across the region and demonstrated the levels of affection in which Jim was held.As a footballer he had few peers. His time with Downpatrick Rec was marked with cup and league successes, culminating in lting the Steel and Sons Cup in front of record attendances at the Crusaders Seaview ground for the first drawn match and the subsequent replay.Supporters from Downpatrick travelled in their thousands, marking the event one of the most widely celebrated sporting achievements of that era. The gate receipts were the highest ever recorded for the annual showpiece of amateur soccer in Northern Ireland, so much so that for the first time the income exceeded the VAT threshold, which meant tax had to be paid.On the day the Rec won that Steel Cup replay, Distillery tried to sign Jim as he left the pitch. He turned them down with a typically firm but gentlemanly refusal and stayed with the Rec for another four years, helping them to add to their cabinet of silverware.Jim lsquoCootrsquo Connolly was a player of exceptional talent. A classy and cultured defender, he is remembered for his unique ability to rise above other players, most of whom had a distinct height advantage, but lacked Jimrsquos trademark for timing his runs and hanging in the air for longer than ought to have been humanly possible. Many a spectator were left speechless after matches, shaking their heads in puzzlement at his exploits. Yes, he was that good.Tony lsquoDartrsquo Curran, who was the Downpatrick Rec goalkeeper, said it was ldquosometimes scary playing behind Jim. ldquoWhen I walked with Coot or talked with him or more often had a beer with him, I felt I was in the presence of greatness.So much so that everyone wanted a part of that, and his we Angie and family had to learn to share Coot because he just made you feel good about yourself. For that we as a community are eternally grateful to them. His footballing ability was absolutely extraordinary. I played behind him and said to him on a few occasions lsquoCoot you scare me. The things you do defy the laws of physics and gravityrsquo. He would jump for a ball start to come down and without touching the ground go up again. I swear it.Tony added: ldquoThe world is a sadder place for his leaving but somewhere up there hersquoll be playing with the guys that have gone before him and maybe BFwill be managing. I hope they will keep me a place on their team.Former Rec manager Jim Prior was devastated to learn of Jimrsquos death. ldquoLike all his former teammates I am cut to ribbons that Jim is no longer with us. As a footballer, he was simply out of this world. The other players on our most successful team were in awe of Jim and all loved him. He had star quality written all over him.He could do things that others couldnrsquot do, whether that was on the training ground or in the toughest of matches. I canrsquot remember him putting in less than a five-star performance.The Recrsquos former club secretary, Patricia Murrayremembers Jim as the baby of the Steel Cup team. ldquoMy deepest and heartfelt sympathies to Angela and all his family and friends. His laugh, smile and craic will be truly missed, Patricia said.Jim Connollyrsquos impact with Downpatrick was repeated at his next clubs, Ards and Killyleagh YC, where he suffered a career ending injury. He had been with the club for just two seasons but left an indelible mark. One of Killyleaghrsquos stalwart players, Philip Jennings, posted his own tribute. ldquoGreat memories of watching Jim for the great Down Rec team and playing with him at Ards and Killyleagh. A real legend in local football, but even more than that, just an absolute gentleman.Despite his injury, Jim ed to football several years later to turn out for the Downshire Hospital, with whom he won an all-Ireland medal winner in  under the management of Brian Cheetham.But the question always remained about what could have become of this precocious talent had he been able to stick with one of English footballrsquos premier clubs.His trials there were cut short by homesickness, more particularly an abiding love for his recently widowed mother. Downpatrick was his anchor. Family, friends, and the Stream Street precinct of his youth were too deeply ingrained for the young Connolly to ever contemplate leaving them behind. It was never a regret for Jim. Indeed,anything, the choice to stay reinforced his passion and love for the area. He perhaps never knew how deeply those feelings of connection were ed by those who had the good fortune to know him.Jimrsquos trials were at Nottingham Forest, Newcastle, and Everton, all three organised by local scout Bill Oakes. Everton came closest to getting his signature after pursuing him back to Downpatrick, although it was later learned that Newcastle too badly wanted to bring him on board.Local sports writer Charlie McStay recalled being contacted in later years by one of the Newcastle coaches who was enquiring about what had happened to Jim. ldquoNewcastle knew they had a gem on their hands, but he slipped through the net.All the coaches rated him at the highest level and believed he would have gone on to become a true star of English football, said Charlie.What a journey that would have been. All the way from Dunleath City and Santos in the Downpatrick Youth League to the pinnacle of professional soccer.Although soccer was Jimrsquos first love, he was an accomplished boxer and in his early days was trained by Owen Kerr, a respected coach who was a friend of world heavyweight champion, Floyd Patterson. Coincidentally, Owen was uncle to Cathal Kerr, who married Jimrsquos sister Bronagh. Small world!Jim also played juvenile and senior football for the Downpatrick Russell Gaelic Union, which this week remembered him as ldquomore than just a great footballer.An online RGU statement said: ldquoHe was one of the nicest guys you could ever meet. A true gentleman with an infectious laugh, he will be sadly missed by all who knew him.Away from sport, Jim trained as a mechanic and later became a minibus driver at Knockevin School and the local hospitals. He then joined Ulsterbus as a driver at the Downpatrick depot and rounded off his career as a groundsman at the Delamont estate. Always active, alwaysbusy that was the Jim Connolly way.Throughout his le, Jimrsquos singular passion was his family and friends. He was devoted to his we Angela mdash the couple were together from their teenage days and were rarely seen apart mdash and to his children, Aurla, Blaine and Clare. Nothing brought him greater happiness also than the birth of his grandchildren, Ruby, Darcy, Fianna, Fiachra, Grace and Eve. He is also survived by brothers Pat and Martin, sisters Ann, Marie, Bronagh, and Eilish, by his father-in-law Paddy Teggart, and by sons-in-law Feargal and Jude and his daughter-in-law Megan.Theirs is not a private grief. It is shared by countless hundreds who remember the boy and man who gave so much pleasure and for whom there is always a place in their hearts.Joe McCoubrey.prettyPhoto

title: JobStart scheme to help young people welcomed by MLA
story: THE launch of a new government scheme designed to create job opportunities for young people has been welcomed by local politicians.Department for Communities minister Deirdre Hargey last week launched the poundm JobStart scheme designed to support - year olds facing additional employment challenges due to the impact of Covid-.In addition, the government department has also helped create additional employment opportunities for young people and remove barriers for those seeking employment through the work experience programme and an expanded adviser discretionary fund.Minister Hargey said the Covid- pandemic has had an ldquounprecedented impact on the local economy and labour market and that as part of her departmentrsquos response, it has addressed the anticipated impacts on young people and those who are ready to be re-employed but need help negotiating the process of finding work.ldquoThis has included creating job opportunities and placements for young people providing additional payments towards travel or childcare expenses financial support of up to pound, a year to assist in the removal of barriers to employment and training to help people increase their chances of gaining employment.The JobStart scheme is designed to create opportunities for - year olds by providing positions with employers for a period of six months, increasing to nine months for those who meet additional criteria.An Opportunity Guarantee strand has been added to The Work Experience Programmefeaturing  week placements with the guarantee of an interview for a job or an apprenticeship on completion.Strangford MLA Kellie Armstrong and Downpatrick councillor Dermot Curran have both welcomed the new scheme.Mrs Armstrong said the scheme was originally due to start last year, arguing that many young people may have missed out as a result of its delayed implementation.She continued: ldquoThe roll-out of this scheme is welcome as it will help young people climb back from the pandemic financially, while giving the economy a boost. I encourage them to apply for it.ldquoHowever, it is frustrating it has taken us so long to get to this stage. The rest of the UK benefited from it [the scheme] while Northern Ireland lagged behind which was unacceptable. Something which would be so useful can only lose value as time moves on.The MLA said that during the height of lockdown, people under  were the most impacted in terms of job losses and went from ldquoexpecting a scheme to wonderingone would appear at all, confirming that she has asked for confirmation that the Department for Communities will ensure opportunities from the JobStart scheme will be made available across Northern Ireland and will not just be concentrated around Belfast.Cllr Curran said with lockdown restrictions continuing to ease, any move to create job opportunities for young people is particularly welcome as they have a key role to play in future economic success.ldquoMany young people have bore the brunt of an unparalleled economic situation which has had a massive impact on the provincersquos economy, he continued.ldquoRebuilding the economy will require access to highly skilled and talented young iniduals to enable employers to compete globally and young people, in particular, need to be able to avail of high quality routes into careers.Cllr Curran also highlighted the importance of apprenticeship schemes to assist with economic recovery, and, looking forward, believes it is vital that the Newry, Mourne and Down area has access to highly skilled employers as businesses work to recover from the devastating impact of coronavirus.He said he firmly believes that the enterprise, innovation and entrepreneurship of young people is crucial to the economy..prettyPhoto

title: Lady luck for East Down AC runners
story: THE  Belfast Half Marathon was always going to be a virtual affair due to Covid- restrictions, but that didnrsquot seem to put people off entering and setting their own route in order to chase a personal best for the distance or simply to claim their T-shirt.This event is normally well attended and attracts a raft of spectators, which creates a great atmosphere, but this year it was up to the runners to come up with a way of motivating themselves on the day.East Down AC had several runners who have used this as their incentive to keep churning out the long runs and as the date approached they were well prepared to cover the . miles.It was a case of girl power as all the EDAC athletes who took part were female on this occasion. Joanne Carson is credited with coming up with a pleasing route for her buddies, Helen Vint, Mags Flynn and Cathy Burke.These girls are to be seen most weekends, rain, hail or shine, chalking up miles in and around Downpatrick. Their dedication is most commendable. In their opinion, a half marathon is long enough to challenge the legs but not as draining as a full marathon so you could almost say that it is an enjoyable task.Joanne got them off to a familiar start. They met outside Castlewellan Forest Park on Saturday morning and ran into the park to do three laps of the lake. Nicely warmed up, they then headed out the main road to Newcastle and didnrsquot stop till they were in the grounds of the Slieve Donard hotel.They fairly breezed along and were all within sight of each other as they came to a halt. Cathy andMags were at the head of the pack in one hour  minutes with Helen less than a minute behind.Joanne was just a few seconds over the two hours and more than happy with her run and they all agreed that it was a scenic route.Being at the Percy French and the fact that outside hospitality had conveniently opened the night before, it would have been rude not to have an ice cold beverage to celebrate. Well deserved ladies.And so to Sunday, Suzy Smith often meets with friends and family including Kelly her niece for a long Sunday run.They stay close to home in Ballykinlar where the terrain could be described as lumpy. In fact whichever way they go, there are some challenging hills but these girls are well used to it and tough enough to persevere.Suzy had actually only planned to run a few miles with brother Patrick to encourage him on his way to the half marathon distance but she was enjoying it so much that she ran on and on until before she knew it, she had covered the entire . miles.Despite this only being her second time to complete a half marathon, she finished in a very respectable time of two hours and five minutes.Who knows how well she could doshe was participating in an official race Kelly meanwhile had struck a brisk pace from the off and followed her own rhythm easing ahead in the early stages. She has been running very well in training and it was no surprise that despite the gradients involved, she ended up with a personal best time of one hour  minutes.Again there is no doubt on a flatter course with other runners to chase, there will be improvement to come but for now both Smiths were content with their efforts and so they should be, well done..prettyPhoto

title: Leader and inspiration
story: FINNEBROGUE Artisan has promised to continue the legacy of founding chairman Denis Lynn who died in a quad bike accident at the weekend.Hailed as an ldquoinnovator and visionary, Mr Lynn died following a tragic incident at his home in Killyleagh on Sunday.Mr Lynnbecame synonymous with his Downpatrick-based firm, which now employs , people over four local sites.On buying Finnebrogue Estate on the outskirts of the town in , the former potato chip seller turned to beef and deer farming and established Finnebrogue as the biggest venison processor and supplier in the UK.He then produced quality sausages, supplying Marks and Spencer and other leading retailers, and developed the nitrate-free bacon brand, Naked Bacon, in .More recently, Finnebrogue has ersied into developing meat-free products.The firmrsquos senior management team will now lead the business with non-executive director David Manning stepping up as interim-chairman and non-executive director Colin Walsh as interim deputy-chairman.A company statement paid tribute to Mr Lynn, who is survived by his we Christine, daughters Kerry, Clare, Tara and Ciara, and his wider family circle.It said: ldquoDenis was an innovator and a visionary with an infectious passion for delivering positive change for the planet and its people. He leaves behind an extraordinary list of achievements.ldquoDenis also leaves behind Finnebrogue and a vision for its future. Finnebrogue was his creation. It now falls on all of us mdash the Finnebrogue family mdash to continue his outstanding work.The statement promised to continue the companyrsquos founderrsquos work in the way he would have wanted.It continued: ldquoDenis was our founder, leader and inspiration. We will best honour his memory by invoking his passion for making food the best it can possibly be, without being bound by the way itrsquos always been done mdash and by trying every day to make the world a better place.Mr Lynnrsquos accomplishments and contribution to employment in Downpatrick and local charitable causes were lauded by politicians.South Down MP Chris Hazzard said his ldquothoughts were with his family and friends and everybody at Finnebrogue who will miss him greatly.Strangford MP Jim Shannon remembered the businessman as a friend of over  years, having first met him when they were both running businesses.He said: ldquoAlways cheerful and approachable Denis was eager to help and assist and his charitable donations were often done under the radar but made a big dference for those who needed it.ldquoAt this time of grief and sorrow, I would like to convey to the family my sincere condolences. I know that his legacy will live on through his family and thriving business.DUP MLA Jim Wells spoke of how shocked the community were to learn of the sudden death, adding: ldquoHe made a huge contribution to the economic le of the area.Former SDLP leader and South Down MP Baroness Margaret Ritchie praised Mr Lynn for developing ldquoworld class products and new brands in the food processing industry such as the specialised bacon.She added: ldquoDenis showed what hard work and determination can achieve. My deepest sympathies to his widow and family who will feel his loss.South Down MLA Colin McGrath described Mr Lynn as ldquoan entrepreneur who worked hard and delivered hundreds of jobs to the Downpatrick area.He added: ldquoHe cared about our area and his charity work was understated and had impact, especially in Africa.Local DUP councillor Billy Walker described Mr Lynn as a ldquohugely successful businessman and a ldquogreat ambassador for the district.ldquoDenis was an absolute gentleman and I was privileged to know him for many years, Mr Walker said.ldquoHe was extremely generous and supported many fundraisers I was involved in. He was always the first person to put his hand in his pocket.ldquoOnly recently he sponsored a book of poems written by a Killyleagh woman after her son had been killed.ldquoI would like to offer my heartfelt sympathy to his we and family.SDLP Councillor Terry Andrews spoke of his sadness at learning of the businessmanrsquos death.ldquoMr Lynn did so much for the local community and I will be keeping his family and friends in my thoughts and prayers.Alliance councillor Patrick Brown described the news of Mr Lynnrsquos death as ldquodevastating.ldquoThis was a tragic accident and one which has cruelly claimed the le of Denis when he had so much more le to live.UUP councillor Alan Lewis praised Mr Lynnrsquos entrepreneurial abilities.ldquoAnyone who has the vision and courage to set up, run and maintain their own business does so with dedication and commitment to energise and invest within their local community, he said.ldquoBy recognising opportunities and homegrown talent, he developed and built a brand recognised nationally as well as internationally.Mr Lynn supported a number of organisations, including the Killyleagh Summer League which organises soccer for local children.League chairman Chris Hagan thanked Mr Lynn for ldquowillingly, quietly and generouslyrsquorsquo stepping in when the league sought its first title sponsor in its -year history.ldquoHe gladly agreed when we first asked for support in , Mr Hagan said. ldquoThe fit was perfect as we sought a brand that was local, appropriate and ethical for sponsoring sporting activity by boys and girls,rsquorsquoldquoWe were not the first organisation in the Killyleagh area to benefit from his interest, but his link to the league was a partnership with young people that genuinely pleased him.Mr Hagan added: ldquoHe leaves behind an extraordinary list of achievements including inspiring young people for the future.rsquorsquoMr Lynnrsquos funeral will take place on Friday..prettyPhoto

title: Local students shine in examinations
story: PUPILS at Mourne Stars Speech and Drama are as resilient as ever as they have continued to take part in lessons during lockdown.Classes have been able to go ahead via zoom and have been as popular as ever.Drama teacher Clare Murnin is extremely impressed with the resilience of each and every one of her pupils, how determined they are to learn and enjoy drama, no matter what is happening in the world.In class they continued to enjoy performing poetry, s and Improvisations, all the while developing their confidence, self-esteem and communication skills.Clare has pupils in Newcastleand has been teaching sessions to pupils in Moneydarragh Hub in Annalong, Newry Street Unite, Kilkeel, and has recently had some pupils take part in a taster course in association with Jason Magee School of Music.Just before Easter a number of Clarersquos pupils took part in graded examinations. These exams were in speech and drama and acting.Clare said: ldquoFor the speech and drama grades the pupils have the opportunity to study poetry and stories. They learn to recite these with confidence, clear expression and articulation.ldquoThey learn how to discuss their work with the examiner and it is wonderful to watch their communication skills develop. It is amazing to see how each of these pupils have developed in confidence and the exams are a wonderful way to mark this achievement.ldquoAs pupils progress through the grades, they learn so much about how the voice works along with literary techniques which, in turn, helps them with literacy and English at school.She continued: ldquoSome senior pupils chose to do the acting pathway which involved them studying plays and monologues and understand how to develop characterisation, all the while enhancing their voice, movement, gesture and facial expression.ldquoThe acting exams are very like the audition process which some of the pupils have taken part in before for local casting agents. They all worked extremely hard last term and were all very deserving of their results. A huge well done to each of them for their determination to do well.A few pupils also took part in the Newry Musical Virtual Feis and received ious awards. Watch this space for updates on their achievements as and when they receive their awards.Missing from the photos are Brendan Morganand Feargal Leblanc ..prettyPhoto

title: Minister gives backing to £55m park investment
story: WORK on a multi-million pound revitalisation project at Castlewellan Forest Park has been given the seal of approval by Stormont rural affairs minister Edwin Poots.He visited the park recently to view work currently underway at the Bothy Yard and highly acclaimed Arboretum as part of four-year pound.m scheme which is being backed by the National Lottery Heritage Fund and Newry, Mourne and Down Council.The project will signicantly enhance facilities at the sprawling park, with the lottery funding earmarked to restore a number of key features to help maximise its tourism potential.The Heritage Fund has already provided almost pound, in financial assistance and has now backed that up with an additional pound.m, with the local authority investing pound.m in the revitalisation scheme.Construction work has already commenced at the Bothy Yard in the forest park thanks to a pound, funding boost from the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairsand the EU.During his visit, Mr Poots met with Dr Sally Montgomery, chairwoman of the Task and Finish Project Board, and council chairwoman Laura Devlin, who provided him with an update on the work so far and the exciting plans for the future.The Stormont minister described the Bothy Yard and Arboretum projects in an area of outstanding natural beauty as an ldquoexcellent example of what his department is doing to support investment in rural tourism and the natural and built heritage of Northern Ireland.ldquoTourism remains vitally important to our rural economy and through the rural tourism scheme with my department investing just over poundm across  projects, all of which are unique in their own right, he said.Mr Poots said he was delighted that following funding provided by DAERA and the local authority, the National Lottery Heritage Fund had made a substantial financial offer to allow the council take forward other works within the forest park which will see its masterplan come to fruition.ldquoI believe that DAERArsquos vision and initial investment went a long way to levering in this additional funding and I wish the local council every success with this project, he added.Cllr Devlin said the DAERA investment, alongside that provided by the local authority, will ensure the Bothy is reinstated as a working hub of the Arboretum.ldquoFollowing the investment, visitors will be able to learn about the rich natural heritage that the forest park has to offer through interpretation in the Stove Conservatory, enriching the visitor experience in the park, she added.Work on the main restoration project at the forest park is scheduled to start in the summer and complete by December , with the local authority agreeing a lease for the core areas within the park from the Forest Service until .Proposed work includes new landscape and drainage within the Grange courtyard, a new pedestrian path from the entrance gates to the main car park, a new vehicular road off Castle Avenue to the existing car park. There will also be a new traffic control barrier at Castle Avenue.Caravan spaces will be relocated with the feature entrance gates at the Castle Avenue entrance restored, alongside the restoration of the Grange courtyard buildings and the reconstruction of a derelict building block.The parkrsquos th century greenhouse is also being restored with the reconstruction of the propagation house and cold frames, while one of several outbuildings will be converted to an office and volunteer space.Elsewhere, visitor facilities will be created in the Stove Conservatory including an interpretation centre, with a  lt installed to provide access to the terrance for people with reduced mobility.Since , the local authority has been progressing with plans to restore the natural and built heritage of the forest park with several key stakeholders including the Forest Service.The councilrsquos vision is to create a heritage-led destination which protects the heritage of Castlewellan Forest Park for future generations, whilst also providing opportunities for local people and visitors to learn more about the landscape..prettyPhoto

title: Peatlands strategy call
story: STORMONT environment minister Edwin Poots has been asked to set up a cross-departmental taskforce to respond to the recent malicious wildfire in the Mournes.The call by South Down MP Chris Hazzard comes after an online petition was set up a by a Newcastle resident urging Newry, Mourne and Down Council to ban the sale of disposal barbecues.The huge blaze mdash which took almost three days to control mdash was battled by  firefighters at its height and was one of the biggest ever gorse fires ever witnessed in Northern Ireland.Almost  acres of precious habitat were destroyed and the scars left in an area of outstanding natural beauty will take many years to heal.Huge flames fanned by winds and dficult terrain presented firefiighters with signicant challenges as they worked around the clock to save as much of a landscape teaming with le as they could during what was a complex operation.The environmental impact of the blaze which could be seen up to  miles away has been described as ldquoimmeasurable.Mr Hazzard has this week urged the environment minister to publish what he described as a ldquolong overdue draft peatlands strategy which would help protect and manage some of the countryrsquos most fragile habitats.The MP said that having watched the huge gorse fires engulf the Mournes, many feared that the days and weeks ahead would be dficult.Having now visited the affected area in the Mournes, Mr Hazzard he was ldquogenuinely shocked at the extent of the devastation.He continued: ldquoMuch of the area is scarred with the charred remains of fragile flora and fauna, with the sickening evidence of the deadly impact of this fire on local wildle plain to see. Local agencies cannot be left alone to pick up the pieces and restore this fragile habitat.ldquoThe environment minister must urgently convene a cross-departmental taskforce that brings together the experience, focus and most importantly, resources, in order to meet the unprecedented challenges in rejuvenating this area.Mr Hazzard said the scenes of environmental destruction left in the Mournes as a result of the inferno show the urgent need to protect precious habitats, especially our peatlands.He added: ldquoIf managed correctly, peatlands play an important role in supporting rich ecosystems, improving water quality and also protecting our communities from the localised consequences of climate change.ldquoFor some time now a draft peatlands strategy has sat with the minister awaiting publication there can be no more delay. Minister Poots must publish this strategy as soon as possible.Meanwhile, the petition urging a ban on the sale of disposal barbecues in shops and supermarkets is gathering increasing support.The resident behind the petition said that every year a number of businesses push the the sale of cheap, disposable barbecues, which are frequently taken to be used in parks and green spaces, often without the landowners permission.ldquoIn many cases, having already scorched the ground below, these barbecues are frequently left, giving rise to wild fires. Disposable barbecues are bad for the environment in terms of use and disposal, said the resident.ldquoThese barbecues are made using unsustainable materials from tropical forests in South Africa and South America.ldquoThey canrsquot be recycled, burn grass and typically result in scattered litter. Just like Chinese sky lanterns which the local council previously took action on and which were also once acceptable, the time has come to ban disposable barbecues.The resident said disposable barbecues represent a ldquohuge fire risk, burn the ground underneath them, are often left as litter and contain sharp pieces that can harm animalstrodden on.She added: ldquoThey are used in beauty spots, wildle reserves and on beaches and are just left smouldering. They make it far too easy for people to be irresponsible by putting them directly on the ground and then leaving them there afterwards.ldquoLiving in an area of natural beauty we have many areas were people see fit to light a barbecue. The recent events have shown us we cannot take the risk. The earth is too fragile and the danger to humans and wildle is too great. These cheap, lightweight disposable barbecues, are not to be socially acceptable any longer..prettyPhoto

title: Rosaleen praises family on her 100th birthday
story: BORN the day before Northern Ireland came into being  years ago, Rosaleen Rogan celebrated her centenary in style on Sunday.The long and happy le of the devoted parishioner was celebrated at Holy Family Church in Teconnaught with a special Mass dedicated to her by the parish priest, Father Brendan Smyth.The mother-of-five, grandmother to  and great-grandmother to  was greeted by her family and friends staggered throughout the day after the service and at home.Said by her family to ldquostill buzzing on Monday, Mrs Rogan was overwhelmed by the amount of cards, flowers and Mass bouquets given to her to mark her momentous day.As May  in  was recently decreed as the day Northern Ireland was constituted, Mrs Rogan, who lives with her daughter, Mrs Stella Rea in Magheralone, is one of the last surviving Irish-born citizens in Northern Ireland.Her th birthday was recognised by both states with a card from the Queen and a letter from Irish President Michael D Higgins along with a cheque for pound,.Mrs Rogan was also very touched to have been sent a Papal blessing, which was a gt from the parish organised by Fr Smyth, and a letter of congratulations from the Lord Lieutenant of Down, Mr David Lindsay.She was also delighted to receive a visit from family friend and former South Down MP, Baroness Margaret Ritchie who helped the family mark the birthday.Mrs Rogan, who hails from Annacloy, was also joined on Sunday by her two surviving brothers, Joe and Maurice McGrath, with their wives and her sister Marie at the Mass.She is the widow of the late Joe Rogan, a well-known shoemaker and repairer in Drumaness, and often helped him with stitching jobs in the business over the years.The couple shared a devotion to their faith and celebrated  years of marriage on September . Sadly, Mr Rogan died the following March.They had five children mdash Mary Joe, Magdalene, Joe, Imelda and Stella. Her son, Joe, is well-known in Castlewellan for running his former business, JRrsquos shop and she joined him last month to celebrate his retirement.Before she was married, Mrs Rogan worked in service and looked after children at several homes in Belfast and Bangor, but when the Second World War broke out she ed home to help out on the family farm.Mrs Rogan met her husband through attending parish activities in the mid s. They married in September , , and started their long le together, living in Magheralone and the Four Roads in Drumaness.When asked how she accounts for her long le, Mrs Rogan replied: ldquoHard work, good company and a loving family. It was all down to the Lord, it was nothing that I did.One of the highlights of her le was when she was honoured in September , by being invited to Knock Shrineas a special guest of honour to meet the new Papal Nuncio, Archbishop Jude Thaddeus Okolo.Mrs Rogan was selected as someone who dedicated her le to prayer. She and her daughters, Mary Joe Walker, Imelda Savage and Stella Rea, marked the annual pilgrimage to Knock as one of the most important dates in the year. She was also presented with a certicate during Mass as the oldest grandparent there that day.Mrs Rogan is a famed seamstress and her family say that there is nothing she canrsquot turn her hand to, and shersquos still sought out to help them with the odd stitching job.Mrs Rea adds: ldquoIf therersquos a particularly dficult tear, the saying usually is you may ask Granny Rogan. She also took up knitting again during the lockdown and knits squares for prayer blankets.ldquoMummy used to go to thelocal bingo many many years ago with her friends and neighbours but still enjoys a game with family around the kitchen table.ldquoEvery Easter she joins the grandchildren and great grandchildren painting the eggs to get ready for rolling.Mrs Rogan loved working outdoors and was a keen gardener. Today she enjoys the lively company of her great-grandchildren and has also got comfortable with technology, video-calling other family members who are not at home and watching Mass at Holy Family Church online.Her family hope to have her attending Mass every Sunday as soon as possible..prettyPhoto

title: St Kevin’s Camogie Club now a reality
story: A NEW camogie club has been formed in East Down.St Kevinrsquos Camogie Club is the result of the coming together of Teconnaught GAC and Drumaness GAC, which both have strong camogie traditions.The two clubs share a sporting history mdash many years ago they united to form a football team also titled St Kevinrsquos.The exciting new venture materialised after a conversation between chairperson Maria Ryan, who hails all the way from Silvermines in Co Tipperary, but now lives in Teconnaught, and vice-chair Cathy Mason, a Drumaness native, about keeping the tradition of camogie alive.ldquoAfter endless conversations with Teconnaught chairman Barry Carville over the years, he brought it to the Teconnaught committeersquos attention, said Maria.ldquoOnce he did this, word got out about the interest of camogie around the community. This is what led to a conversation with Cathy, who had a shared love and passion for the sport, she continued.ldquoWe both agreed it would be amazingwe could bring young girls together to play camogie. The success of St. Kevinrsquos would not have been possible without the drive from both parishes.The newly formed committee is made up of a number of associated members from both clubs, who all share the same common goal of teaching camogie to as many girls as possible whilst ensuring a longevity to develop and establish the club.Cathy said it was ldquoan absolute honour to play a part in the creation of St Kevinrsquos.ldquoAs a Drumaness Gael I know that a very special lady, Annie Gelston, a Drumaness camogie legend, will be looking down with pride, said Mason.ldquoI would like to say a
